What's the status of this @kkbankol-ibm ?
We refer to this as ECA (event condition action) -currently you can do this by returning any error from the condition action. There's a proposal to improve this which I'll cross link.
See https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/995#issuecomment-265589172.  Closing as duplicate.

This comment is more for clarity on this issue.

This is the link I've referenced: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/reference.md#system-limits
This is the command I used to create the action:
wsk action create --docker -t 300000 my-action my-docker-container

The action I created sometimes takes over a minute to complete; when it takes less time it works, when it takes more it terminates early at 1 minute and crashes. Looking at the link provided, the timeout limit can be set to in the range of 100ms to 300000ms. However, if you try to set it over 60000ms (1 min) the action I created still terminates at the 1 minute marker. Is that what this issue is trying to address or should I submit another bug?
Hey @markusthoemmes, this should be ready to be merged in unless you see any issues with it

I'll speculate you're doing a blocking invoke, in which case refer to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#creating-and-invoking-a-simple-javascript-action section 4 (the connection is only held open for a maximum of 60s).

@markusthoemmes I'm trying to understand what is the advantage of coupling `identity` (represented by the AuthKey) with the `namespaces`.  I thought the AuthKey is used to authenticate a user/developer and that whether a user is authorized to manage a namespace or not is another concern. Can you share more details to help me understand ?
Sure `wsk --version` makes sense as an alias.
@csantanapr - Ready for re-review/merge.  PG failure due to 2 other unrelated known issues.

I want to explore the third approach for implementing feeds-via connections. I have a Slack outgoing webhook which should hit an OW action's REST endpoint. Slack doesn't allow me to customize it's request header so I cannot pass in my OpenWhisk creds via Basic Auth so requests to OW get rejected. I might be misunderstanding this but I think a "connection" intermediate will help.

Your explanation is nice but would be great if you can provide some code samples or snippets at the very least as I don't know where to start.

Thanks in advance!

thanks @markusthoemmes.

Am I reading correctly that the assumption is that the developer creating the action is also the one invoking the action ? How about actions that are exposed as REST endpoints via the API Gateway which have no OW AuthKey, but have only an OAuth 2 Token from a 3rd party identity provider ? How would we connect these OAuth tokens with some OW credentials used to deploy the action so that we can invoke it ? I think we have to solve this problem if we go down this path. WDYT ? 

This is connected to another aspect that I struggle to understand in OW and that is the separation between the _management_ aspect ( the developers creating and managing actions ) vs the _execution_ aspect (the end-users of an application that invokes actions). In my mind these 2 categories : developers vs end-users have different concerns. They authenticate differently, end-users might not care about namespaces, logs, package names, actions names.

Thinking at the access to the activations and logs of an action, I imagine it's something that concerns more the team that is maintaining that action. If an application that uses an action gets an error back, even though it can access the activations and logs, but if it can't fix the action anyway, what's the utility other than debugging that action and maybe billing ?  

I feel like we're missing another entity that would represent "apps". "Apps" are part of the _execution_ concern b/c they invoke the actions. Apps would subscribe to actions to be able to invoke them. Application info is part of the OAuth token ( the `client_id` that has generated the token ). When an OAuth token is not present we can ask the application to identity itself using an API-KEY for instance.  This way we could show to multiple personas information about activations, _who_ has invoked actions, and _what_ actions. In this way we don't have to solve the problem of matching an OAuth token with an OW Auth Key anymore. We're solving a different problem instead and we can also give access to multiple people to see the analytics for an application. Based on the usage data we can also do billing or charge-backs.

> Am I reading correctly that the assumption is that the developer creating the action is also the one invoking the action ?

Any authorized subject can invoke their actions (in their namespace which may be a shared space with other subjects) or actions in another namespace if the action is in a public package. This was and remains the intended behavior.

With the API gw acting as a proxy between end users and actions, the end user does not need whisk credentials. Whether we integrate bearer tokens or other ACL mechanism is orthogonal and should be deferred to a separate discussion (it's valid and there is ongoing work on this front and prototypes from @starpit). In this model, the end user doesn't see the activations and should be indifferent to how the REST call is serviced. What you call the management aspect, in this way, falls on the developer(s) of the actions that implement the REST calls.
It's worth noting this change is semantic preserving for openwhisk.

@mdeuser  can you please provide a sample swagger file for your point : use a swagger file with >1 paths, > 1 operations per path, and a title. validate.
@nwspeete-ibm - the `wsk` CLI can create the swagger for you.  Just use the CLI to create the API as usual, then issue `wsk api get .... > myapi.swagger.json` to export the API in swagger format

@pjdurai Did I understand your issue correctly: you're deploying openwhisk behind a firewall and want to route API traffic from outside to the openwhisk router on the inside? (Or do you have some hybrid deployment of the openwhisk containers where some are outside and some are inside the firewall?)

Actually my concern is the other way round. I am trying to install/run openwhisk behind a corporate proxy server (All out-going traffic in my network goes through this one proxy server, usually specified in  https_proxy environment variable).

I am unable to complete openwhisk installation in an Ubuntu 14.04 VM because it halts when the containers try to download packages from internet. I haven't found a good way to specify this proxy to applications running inside the docker containers.

Thus I was wondering how others are doing it.

Thanks

In the meanwhile `docker-compose` support has arrived here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-devtools/tree/master/docker-compose . Currently it downloads the code, it compiles it, and it starts an instance of OpenWhisk locally.

Suggest making the verb optional with get as default. --method to override. I'd expect this is the common case and cuts down on number of positional args which can be confusing to someone just starting to use this or kick the tires.

Is there anything site specific in those freshly built containers ?
If not, it would be way more convenient to have the containers uploaded to docker hub and just provide a docker-compose file.
Saves a lot of people the hassle (and CPU cycles) of building openwhisk and the containers.

@csantanapr - merged
@rabbah @cbickel It would be good to ask th epolicy for Apache; I would assume you would leave the earliest (year) copyright "as is" and only update to 2017 as you go/add new function.

> it would be way more convenient to have the containers uploaded to docker hub

👍 @seriousme . Actually `docker-compose.yaml` is ready for that; there's no build instruction. Once the images are available in Docker Hub we'll skip the build step in the Makefile, leaving it optionally. There's already a separate `make docker` command in the Makefile that does the build.

At the same time, here's something interesting:

```bash
> docker images | grep "whisk/invoker\|whisk/controller\|whisk/nodejs6action\|zoo\|kafka\|openwhisk/apigateway\|consul\|registrator\|redis\|couchdb" | awk '{s+=$7} END {print s " MB"}'
2880.07 MB
```
The runtime containers are already on dockerhub fwiw.

Test environment local Whisk installation. latest driver Feb 10.
Changed line #72 in ContainerUtils.scala to :
**val fileHandleLimit = Array("--ulimit", "nofile=512:512")**

1. testet with above action code the limit boundary (before and after the code change)
2. running a load test with 8 action types to verify system behaves as before.
3. run the above action code (opening 512 file handles) during load test

All tests successful.

@cbickel we need to open an issue for this pr and discuss the strategy (for example: You can't enable this without disabling the cache. Tracking system load will need to be global across controllers. Should we separate CRUD vs Activate? Do we allow load balancers to steal load? Etc.).

Also, need to reference the issue from the Apache dev list.
@rabbah With the new implementation the error from an action will be propagated to the encapsulating sequence. I think we have tests for this. Close if you agree.

I think with the new implementation the sequence will not fail silently. I think the sequence will fail with the error returned by the "faulty" action, but if any "good" actions precede the faulty one, they will be executed. We need a test for this.
There does appear to be a gap with internal errors not surfacing correctly. Will open a separate issue. The history for that comment dates back to pipe.js.

No, I directly use wsk. Should that behave this way without -i?
Yes. Your local certificate is not trusted if you used the one generated by openwhisk.
Even if it were trusted you can't create certs for IPs. So the part `doesn't contain any IP SANs` alludes to that. So in any case you have to use `-i` for dev envs.
